channel.title: Clinical Machine Learning
channel.description: Recent content on Clinical Machine Learning

item.title: Research
item.description: .jumptarget::before { content:""; display:block; height:80px; /* fixed header height*/ margin:-80px 0 0; /* negative fixed header height */ } a.section{ color:#A31F34; } a:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color:#A31F34; } .section{ font-size: 1.2em; } Our lab is broadly interested in advancing machine learning and artificial intelligence, and using these to transform health care. We currently have four main focus areas: Clinical Prediction Probabilistic and Causal Inference Sequence Modeling and Non-stationarity Medical Knowledge Extraction

item.title: Software
item.description: a {color: #A31F34;} For latest projects, see our Github. Example software includes: Deep Markov Models: Theano code for implementing Deep Markov Models using variational inference during learning to maximize the likelihood of the observed data Low-Dimensional Medical Concepts: Code for AMIA CRI 2016 paper “Learning Low-Dimensional Representations of Medical Concepts” Health Knowledge Graph: Learned Health Knowledge Graph from emergency room data as featured in Nature Scientific Reports

item.title: Contact Us
item.description:
a {color: #A31F34;} Email David’s email: dsontag {@ | at} mit.edu
FAQs How can I join the group as a PhD student? Graduate admissions are handled at the department level at MIT, so please first apply to the MIT EECS or MIT MEMP departments. For advice on CS PhD admissions, Jean Yang and Philip Guo have written useful guides. How can I join the group as a UROP/SuperUROP or MEng student?

item.title: Mission
item.description: Machine Learning Perspective Making ML work in high-stakes settings Recently developed techniques in machine learning have proven adept at solving problems in computer vision, natural language processing, board games, video games, and other domains where computers had previously struggled to outperform humans. However, deployment in high-stakes settings is still limited, for good reasons: Predictive models alone may be insufficient - we may care about causal questions (as in personalized medicine), not just predictive ones.

item.title: People
item.description: Our team consists of post-docs, students, research scientists, and clinical collaborators. For information about how to join us, see our FAQ section.
